Posts.Content: Jul 3, 2015 07:22AM Golden01 wrote: Remember to breathe! There is no easy way through this week because what you are going through is hard. What I found helped was mindless television (Sex in the City, Arrested Development, Parks and Recreation), funny movies, walks to the park, and time with friends and family. Most of all, remember to breathe. I actually had to ask co-workers to tell me to breathe if they noticed I was holding my breath! It especially happened when I was at red lights. I think I was a little bit like a two-year-old having a temper tantrum. If I held my breath long enough, maybe this would all go away. Sometimes, I think the fear just took my breath away. My BS said it best, you must feel like your world has stopped. That summed it up for me. Sending good wishes.
Posts.Title: Biopsy Monday PamelaR2015 PamelaR2015

Posts.Content: Jan 31, 2015 01:54PM Golden01 wrote: Most important, remember to breathe! When I was in your spot and waiting for tests, I often found myself holding my breath and had to have others remind me to breathe. I felt like a two year old and if I just held my breath long enough, I'd get my way and it would all go away. Walks in the park, funny movies, mindless television helped me.

Posts.Title: stage IIIB and mastectomy need advice pls zohra pp729

Posts.Content: Apr 10, 2013 10:39PM Golden01 wrote: How old is your mother? My Mom developed breast cancer a few  years before I did. She was 83 at the time and her mind was made up for a double mastectomy as soon as she got the phone call that the biopsy showed cancer. She wanted no additional discussion or further consideration. She and my brother saw the surgeon on a Thursday, I flew in from out-of-state over the weekend, and she had the BMX on the following Tuesday. Her surgery was just a week from when she got the phone call about the biopsy. Scheduling the surgery quickly and having a BMX was what was important to her. Her cancer was Stage II. She had an uncomplicated recovery and never looked back. She's 88 now and doing well. Stayed with me after my BMX and told my PS that she didn't have reconstruction "because of my age".
Posts.Title: stage IIIB and mastectomy need advice pls zohra pp729

Posts.Content: Oct 1, 2012 09:44PM - edited Oct 2, 2012 12:46AM by Golden01 It actually was good for me to stop as I was having hip pain. The MO never mentioned that it might be due to the Tamoxifen (did find that out later from these boards and my pharmacist). He gave me an order for x-rays to look for bone mets if the pain didn't get better in about two weeks (the two weeks were over the holidays, Merry Christmas!). I stopped the Tamoxifen on January 1st and the hip pain went completely away within a few days. I didn't go for the x-rays.
Posts.Title: Terrified of coming off tamox for surgery rozem fluffqueen01

Posts.Content: Oct 31, 2013 06:20AM Golden01 wrote: I think the surgery choices were the hardest ones I had to make when I was diagnosed with BC nearly two years ago. Know that as hard as it is, you'll make the right decision for you and your situation. I had a lumpectomy and then had to proceed to MX due to bad margins. My BS was clear that there was no medical indication for me to have a BMX but it needed to be a personal decision. I had a BMX on 9/8/11. The decisions about surgery were very-very hard for me to make. What helped me the most on the decision to have a BMX was a fact sheet from the National Cancer Institute (NCI). Here's the link: www.cancer.gov/cancertopics/fa.... The info has been updated since I had to make my decision and may be helpful to you. We also saw an ACS Cancer Navigator that helped us talk through the options and helped us know we had left no stone unturned in making our decision. Turns out, they found "flat atypia" in my other breast and both the PS and MO have indicated they felt that I would have been back for treatment for cancer in that breast at some point. Even if they had not found anything, I know I made the right decision for me. Good wishes to you as you work through these difficult decisions.
Posts.Title: Lumpectomy vs masectomy Grk1732 Beesie

Posts.Content: Sep 2, 2014 05:33AM Golden01 wrote: Denial has at times been an effective coping mechanism for me. It gives me enough space until I'm ready to handle the what I am facing. I'm three years out from my BC diagnosis and, earlier this year, I found myself not making any doctor's appointments except for the oncologist.  In fact, I had two oncology appointments where my MO went over the same list of appointments that I should be keeping (Gyn, BS, PS, eye doctor, dentist, primary care, hand surgeon to check out unexplained bone pain, etc.). I had no reason for not making those appointments. Finally, I figured out that even though I would go to the MO, staying away from all the other doctors was a way of pretending that I didn't have cancer. Once I figured that out, I made the appointments and have seen all the doctor's except I still need to go see the eye doctor (who knew BC can go to the eyes, that's what he shared with me on my last visit, no wonder I stay away!).
Posts.Title: Denial tequillakma eym266

Posts.Content: Sep 1, 2012 09:28AM Golden01 wrote: Absolutely, it can be nothing! Sounds like you have good doctors that will help you figure it out. After I was diagnosed last year, a friend suggested I get all my old mammagram records to help me in deciding what kind of surgery I should choose. I did that and was amazed at the number of times over the years (I'm a lot older than you and had 20 years of records!) that I'd been called back in for an ultrasound or other follow up. All turned out to be benign (cysts, etc.). I honestly didn't even remember that once I heard there wasn't a problem. This is really hard as it's a long weekend and you can't get information until next week. Enjoy your little one, think precious thoughts about your baby on the way, and know that doing something fun and enjoyable may be the most important thing to focus on for now.

Posts.Content: Jun 11, 2013 08:36AM - edited Jun 11, 2013 08:38AM by Golden01 I think the surgery choices were the hardest ones I had to make when I was diagnosed with BC nearly two years ago. Know that as hard as it is, you'll make the right decision for you and your situation.  I had a lumpectomy and then had to proceed to MX due to bad margins. My BS was clear that there was no medical indication for me to have a BMX but it needed to be a personal decision. I had a BMX on 9/8/11. The decisions about surgery were very-very hard for me to make.  It was hard to know what to do but a friend, who has been through this breast cancer journey, suggested I get all my mammogram records as that had helped  her in making her decision. I did that and realized that over the past 20 years, I've  had a number of problems on both breasts (bleeding, cysts, etc.), each time the problems were found to be benign and I never thought about the problems again. What helped me the most on the decision to have a BMX was a fact sheet from the National Cancer Institute (NCI). Here's the link:www.cancer.gov/cancertopics/fa.... NCI listed six reasons a woman might consider a BMX. I had three of the six! I circled them as my husband and I went over the fact sheet together. It was an easy decision after seeing those circles so clearly on the NCI list. We also saw an ACS Cancer Navigator that helped us talk through the options and helped us know we had left no stone unturned in making our decision. Turns out, they found "flat atypia" in my other breast and both the PS and MO have indicated they felt that I would have been back for treatment for cancer in that breast at some point. Even if they had not found anything, I know I made the right decision for me. Good wishes to you as you work through these difficult decisions.

Posts.Content: Jan 30, 2016 08:37AM Golden01 wrote: I think remembering to breathe is most important. I literally would find myself holding my breath (especially at red lights, along with the gripping the steering wheel). I even asked people I worked with to notice and remind me to breath. The other thing I found helpful was when I just had "enough" of breast cancer, we'd just set it aside and my husband and I would go for a walk to the park, see a funny movie, or go out to eat. We could pick the breast cancer stuff back up the next day. Once I got into treatment, mindless funny television worked for me. Good wishes all around.

Posts.Content: Dec 28, 2013 10:44AM Golden01 wrote: Does anyone know when the results of the TAILORx trial will be out? I would have gotten chemo if I'd been able to be in the trial (Oncotype 27), did not after a second opinion consultation at an NCI cancer research center and careful consideration. I remember sorting out all the info as hard and the waiting for results even harder. For some reason,  my BS didn't order the test but I had to wait until I saw the oncologist and he really pushed on whether I'd consider chemo or not before he would order the test. Seemed silly to me at the time as how could I make a decision on chemo without the Oncotype results?

Posts.Content: Dec 28, 2013 01:21PM Golden01 wrote: My MO concern about ordering the Oncotype absolutely was related to cost. He was clear that if I had already made my mind up against chemo, the test was unnecessary. I know that I made the best decision for me based on the info we had at the time. I wish the TailorX results were coming sooner to help women today who are in the same boat I was in two years ago.

Posts.Title: My worst fear come true! Milane Blessings2011

Posts.Content: Dec 12, 2012 10:20AM Golden01 wrote: Just be there! Don't rearrange her kitchen. Let her do everything she can and wants to do (she may want to spend time with the 5 year old while you cook, she may want a day out with friends while someone else cleans the bathrooms and vacuums). Make sure she and her husband have some alone time. Know that everyone goes through this journey a little bit differently and some people need information "bit by bit" and others will want it all at once. Do your best to figure out what approach works for you,  your son, and your daughter-in-law and support them in how they move forward. Know that sometimes you may be a bit ahead of them, respect how they process the info and make decisions. Keep as many things as possible "the same" (food, routines for the little one, etc.). Funny movies usually are a help. Stay close to that precious little one so he doesn't get scared too when all the adults are shaking in their boots. Ask her and your son what you can do to provide the best support for them. Don't be offended if their list is different than what you feel might help the most. Make sure your son has somebody (maybe you) that he can talk to. Getting outside often lifts the spirits. There is no "right way" to help someone on this difficult journey. You've come to a good place on Breastcancer.org! As her treatment plan is developed, a number of the discussion threads will provide you great information and support. Remember, just be there.
Posts.Title: Terrified mother in law Momnlaw Letlet

Posts.Content: Feb 12, 2013 08:58AM Golden01 wrote: Remember that sometimes all we have to do is to remember to breathe. When I was first diagnosed, I would find myself holding my breath. I asked others to remind me to breathe. The concious thought of knowing that all I had to do at that moment was to take a breath somehow was a comfort to me. Maybe it will be for you too. Others have posted good words for you. Know you are surrounded by good thoughts.
Posts.Title: Please tell me I will survive this. indenial sutherndiva

Posts.Content: Mar 16, 2014 07:28PM Golden01 wrote: So glad I spotted this thread. I am a little over two years out from getting my permanent implants and developed terrible itching on Thursday that was pretty much constant for two days. Glad to know I am not alone. The pain was deep and intense. Figured out yesterday that I had a really-really stressful day on Thursday. I often feel the "stress" in my pectoral muscles much like others get tight shoulders. I consider it an "early warning" sign that I need to pay attention to how I am feeling. Thursday, I didn't have time to notice anything. I think the muscles just tightened up to the point I had spasm-like pain with intense itching. Once I figured that out yesterday, I took a couple of doses of muscle relaxants left over my surgeries and seem to be fine today. My right one feels like it had a workout yesterday. Go figure.

Posts.Content: Apr 10, 2013 10:24PM Golden01 wrote: My level was in the dreaded "Intermediate" category so my decision was very difficult. My MO recommended chemo, the doctor that heads our University's NCI designated cancer research center recommended against it. I went with her recommendation and my MO was in agreement. The reasons were the small size and type of my tumor (<1 cm, mucinous) and my strong family history of heart disease. I read and re-read the studies on Oncotype and came to the conclusion that the TAILOR RX trial will give the answers down the road for women in our shoes. Until then, we have to make the best decisions that we can and move ahead.
